resources.string: Opens the circuit in a new window.
Shows a short description of this element.
Create a circuit in a seperate window
Opens the dialog as a non modal dialog
Opens help text in the browser. Allows to print the text.
A component for simple add caluclations. Adds the two integer values from input a and input b (a+b). The result will be incremented by one if the carry input is set.
Carry input, if set the result is incremented by one.
If set there was an overflow.
Returns the number of 1-bits in the input value.
Binary AND gate. Returns high only if all inputs are also set high.
One of the input values for the logic operation.
Returns the result of the logic operation.
Stops fast simulation if set to 1.

If the input of this component becomes high, the fast forward clocking is stopped. You can use the component to implement a BRK assembly instruction. Then you can run a simulated processor until a BRK instruction is reached.
A simple button which resets back to its original state (0) when not held down. Outputs a 1 if held down.
Returns 1 if pressed else 0. Resets back to 0 when not held down.
Alternates 0 and 1 with the set clock speed.
A clock signal. Its possible to control it by the real time clock. Clock speed (in Hz) can be set in attributes dialog.
A component for comparing bit values. Compares the binary numbers on input pin a and input pin b and sets the corresponding outputs.
Output is 1 if input a equals input b
Output is 1 if input a is greater then input b
Output is 1 if input a is less then input b
Returns the given value as a constant.
A component which returns a given value as a simple constant value. The value can be set in the attributes dialog.
A connection to ground. Output is always zero.
A connection to the supply voltage. Output is always one.
Connects parts without a wire. All tunnel elements, which have the same net name, are connected together. Works only local, so it is not possible to connect different circuits.

Simple unidirectional switch. In the simulation the switch behaves like an active gate with a trivalent truth table. If the switch is open, the output is in high z state. If the switch is closed, the output state is equal to the input state incl. high z state. So two antiparallel connected switches can keep each other in high or low state, which is not possible with real switches. In addition - unlike real switches - there is no feedback from the output to the input. These restrictions do not have any effect when the input of the switch is connected directly to GND, VDD or a constant. In such a circuit, the simulated switch corresponds to a real switch.
This output returns the input value if the switch is closed, and outputs a high z value if the switch is open.
A simple counter component. The clock input increases the counter. Can be reset back to 0 with the clr pin. The number of bits can be set in the attribute-dialog.
The clock input. A rising edge increases the counter.
Resets the counter value if set to 1.
Overflow output. This pin is set to 1 if the counter has an overflow and returns to zero.
A component used to save two states (one bit). The bit on pin D is stored on a rising edge of pin C.
Input of the bit to be stored.
Control pin to store a bit. The bit on input D is stored on a rising edge of this pin.
Shows a data plot inside of the circuit panel. You can plot complete clock steps or single gate changes.
This input selects the enabled output. The selected output is set to 1. All other outputs are set to 0.
Output {0}. This output is 1 if selected by the sel input.
One selectable output line is 1, all other outputs are set to 0.
Input of the signal to be delayed.
Delays the signal by one gate delay
Delays the signal by on gate delay
A component witch can output the input value to one of the outputs. The other outputs are set to the default value.
This pin selects the output to use.
The value of this input is given to the selected output.
A driver can be used to connect a signal value to another line. The driver is controlled by the sel input. If the sel input is low, the output is in high z state.
The input value of the driver.
Pin to control the driver. If its value is 1 the input is given to the output. If the value is 0, the output is in high z state.
If the sel input is 1 the input is given to this output. If the sel input is 0, this output is in high z state.
A driver can be used to connect a data word to another line. The driver is controlled by the sel input.
The input value of the driver.
Pin to control the driver. If its value is 0 the input is given to the output. If the value is 1, the output is in high z state.
If the sel input is 0 the input is given to this output. If the sel input is 1, this output is in high z state.
This connection outputs the given value.
A input which can be used to connect the circuit if it is included in an other circuit.
Has the possibility to store (J=K=0), set (J=1, K=0), reset (J=0, K=1) or toggle (J=K=1) the stored value. The input values act with a rising edge at input C.
The set input of the flipflop.
The Clock input. A rising edge initiates a state change.
The reset input of the flipflop.
A simple LED can be used to visualize an output value. Accepts a single bit. Lights up when the input is set to 1.
LED Input. LED shines when input is set to 1.
Input {0}. This input in combination with all other inputs define the address of the stored value to be returned.
Returns the stored value at the address set via the inputs.

Gets the output value from a stored table. So this gate can emulate every combinatorial gate. The configuration of the LookUpTable like number of bits or number of inputs can be set up in the attributes dialog.
A component for multiplication. Multiplies the integer numbers on input pin a and input pin b.
Output for the result of the multiplication.
The value of the selected input.
This pin selects the input which value is to output.
A component which uses the value of the sel pin to decide which input value is set to the output.
A combiation of AND and NOT. Returns 0 only if all inputs are set to 1. If on of the inputs is set to 0 the output is set to 1.
A combination of OR and NOT. Returns a 0 if one of the inputs is set to 1. If all inputs are set to 0 the output is also set to 1.
Returns the negated value. A 1 becomes a 0 and a 0 becomes 1.
The input of the NOT gate.
Returns the negated value of the input value. All bits are inverted.
Input of the data word to be negated in 2th complement
Returns the result of the negation in 2th complement.
Binary OR gate. Returns a 1 if one of the inputs is set to 1. If all inputs are set to 0 the output is also set to 0.
A output which can be used to connect the circuit if it is included in an other circuit.
This value is used for te output connection.
A measurement value which can be shown in the data graph.
The address to read and write
The data to be stored in the RAM
If this input is high the output is activated and the data is visible at the output.
If this input is high when the clock becomes high, the the data is stored.
A RAM module with separate inputs for storing and output for reading the stored data.
The address to read and write.
If this input is high the output is activated and the data is visible at the output.
If this input is high when the clock becomes high, the the data is stored.
A RAM module with a bidirectional connection for reading and writing the data.

Used to show a bitmap graphic. This element works similar to a RAM. In addition it shows its content on a grahic screen. Every pixel is represented by a memory address. There are to screens supported to implement screen switching (See input B).
The address to read and write.
If this input is high when the clock becomes high, the the data is stored.
If this input is high the output is activated and the data is visible at the output.
This pin defines the address of data word to be output.
The selected data word. Only readable if "select" input is high.
If the input is high, the output is activated. If it is low, the data output is in high Z state.
A component to save a single bit for an undefined duration. Provides the functions "set" and "reset" the stored bit.
The Control input. A rising edge initiates a state transition.
A component to store integers. The length of the data word can be set in the attributes dialog.
Input pin of the data word to be stored.
Clock. A rising edge stores the value at the D pin.
Enable pin. Storing a value works only if this pin is set high.
Reset Output. Is zero while the circuit is stabilizing.
The output of this component is held low during the initialisation of the circuit. After the circuit has stabilized the output goes to high.
This input controls the upper, horizontal line.
This input controls the upper, right, vertical line.
This input controls the lower, right, vertical line.
This input controls the lower horizontal line.
This input controls the lower, left, vertical line.
This input controls the upper, left, vertical line.
This input controls the middle, horizontal line.
This input controls the decimal point.
Seven Segment Display with a 4 bit input
The value at this input is visualized at the display.
This input controls the decimal point.
Seven Segment Display, every segment has its own input.
Splits or creates a wire bundle or a data bus with more than one bit.
A component for simple substractions. Substracts binary numbers on input a and input b (a-b). If the carry input is set to 1 the result is decremented by 1.
Carry input, if set the result is decremented by one.
Output returns the result of the substraction.
Output returns 1 if an overflow occured.
A component with one input. Toggles the state of the output on a rising edge at the input.
Clock. A rising edgt toggles the output.
Clock. A risig edge writes the value at the input to the terminal window.
The data to write to the terminal
You can write ASCII characters to this terminal. The terminal opens its own window to visualize the output.
Shows a text in the circuit. The text can be changed in the attributes dialog.
A combination of XOR and NOT. The output is 1 if both input bits are equal.
Input a for Exclusive Not Or.
Input b for Exclusive Not Or.
Returns the result of the XNOr operation.
The output is 0 if both input bits are equal.

Describes a test case. In a test case you can describe how a circuit should behave. It can then be automatically checked whether the behavior of the circuit actually corresponds to this description. If this is not the case, a corresponding error message is shown.
A simple keyboard which can be used to input symbols.
If high the output D is active and one keystroke is output.
The last pressed key, or zero if no key is typed.
Simplified bidirectional diode. It is used to implement a wired AND or a wired OR.. This is a ideal diode: There is no voltage drop across a forward-biased diode.

A simplified unidirectional diode, used to pull a wire to ground. It is used to implement a wired AND. Is the input low, also the output is low. In the other cases (input is high or high z) the output is in high z state. So this is a ideal diode: There is no voltage drop across a forward-biased diode.
If the input is low also the output is low. In all other cases the output is in high z state.
If the input is low also the output is low. In all other cases the output is in high z state.

A simplified unidirectional diode, used to pull a wire to VDD. It is used to implement a wired OR. In the simulation the diode behaves like an active gate with a trivalent truth table: Is the input high, also the output is high. In all other cases (input is low or high z) the output is in high z state. So two antiparallel connected diodes can keep each other in high state, which is not possible with real diodes. This is an ideal diode: There is no voltage drop across a forward-biased diode.
If the input is high also the output is high. In all other cases the output is in high z state.
If the input is high also the output is high. In all other cases the output is in high z state.
If a net is in a HighZ state, this resistor pulls the net to high. In any other case this component has no effect.
If the net is in a HighZ state, this resistor pulls the net to ground. In any other case this component has no effect.
Pin {0} in component {1} is not a input or output
A single clock component is necessary. All flip-flops must use this clock signal.
The value {0} has more the one bit.
More then one output is active on a wire
Flip-flop needs to be connected to the clock.
There are more then one clock
There are {0} bits needed, but {1} bits found
No value set for {0} at component {1}
Not all connected outputs have the same bit count
If multiple outputs are connected together, all of them have to be three-state outputs.
No output connected to a wire: {0}
Table to small: One result is required!
Found a pin without a name.
Logic seems to oscillate. To analyse you can run the circuit in single gate step mode.
The remote port is in use! Is there an other instance running?
Number of inputs does not match selector bit count
Bit count of splitter is not matching
Variable {0} is not allowed in CUPL source!
Value {0} in line {1} is not a number!
Expected {0} but found {1} values in line {2}!
No input signals defined in test vector!
No output signals defined in test vector!
Error during execution of a remote command
It's not allowed to connect a pull up and a pull down resistor to a single wire.
The splitter does not support high z inputs! Use a pull up or pull down resisitor.
A splitter which allows high z inputs can only have one input!
If this ammount of cycles is reached without a break signal, an error is created.
The values stored in this element.
This value is set if the circuit is started
A short description of this element and its usage.
The realtime frequency used for the real time clock
Use IEEE 91-1984 shapes instead of rectangular shapes
Example "4,2,2" or "[Bits]*[Count] like "1*16" for 16 single bits.
The Number of Inputs used. Every input needs to be connected.
The size of the component in the circuit.
All nets with identical name are connected together.
Example "4,2,2" or "[Bits]*[Count] like "1*16" for 16 single bits.
Number of bits used for the selector input.
If selected the comparison is performed with signed (2th complement) values.
Sets the initial state of the switch.
With of symbol if this circuit is used as an component in an other circuit.
Reloads the hex file every time the model is started.
This option allows you to move te selector pin to the opposite side of the plexer.
The format used to show the numbers.
If set the input is allowed to be in high-z state.
Max number of steps to show
The maximal number of values stored. If the maximum number is reached, the oldest values are discarded.
The orientation of the Element in the circuit.
If enabled the runtime clock is started when the circuit is started
Show measurement graph in single gatem step mode
The number of lines to show.
The number of characters shown in a single line.
Is set the value is a measurement value and appears in the graph and data table.
The description of the test case. Details of the syntax can be found in the help dialog of the test data editor.
Makes this ROM to program memory. So it can be accessed by an external IDE.
If set the diode is treated as a "blown" or "programmed" diode or fuse. You can change this setting with the key 'p'.
Delete selected single component or group of components.
These attributes effect the behavior if the circuit is included in other circuits.
Settings used to start the simulation
Edits the circuit. Moves a single component or edits its properties.
Runs the circuit until a break is detected by the BRK component.
Imports a circuit as a usable component!
Runs the circuit in single gate step mode
Opens a circuit in a new window
Order the inputs for the usage as nested circuit
Orders the measurement values in the graphical and table view
Order the outputs for the usage as nested circuit
Performs a speed test by calculating the max. clock frequency.
Generates the minimal bool expressions described by a truth table.
Creates a CUPL source file containing the define circuit.
Creates a circuit which reproduces the truth table.
Creates a circuit which reproduces the truth table. Uses JK flip-flops.
Circuit with NAnd gates with two inputs
Use only NAnd gates with two inputs.
Creates a circuit which reproduces the truth table only with NAnd gates.
Circuit with NOr gates with two inputs
Use only NOr gates with two inputs.
Creates a circuit which reproduces the truth table only with NOr gates.
create circuit, use only gates with two inputs
Creates a JEDEC file for the device
You can load the HEX file to a ROM or a LUT.
Create a circuit from an expression.
Runs all test cases in the circuit
Use actual input values as new default values.
Resets all diodes (fuses) to the unprogramed state. The actual fuse configuration is lost!
Shows a list of all available components.
Shows the help dialog describing the actual circuit.
Shows the content of memory components.

Digital
A simple simulator for digital circuits. Written bei H.Neemann in 2016.
The icons are taken from the Tango Desktop Project.
Error during a clock state change
Change needs a restart to take effect!
No ROM found! ROM needs to be set to be program memory.
More then one ROM found! Only one ROM must be set to be program memory.
The clipboard contains no importable data!

To define an expression you can use all most common notations:
And: "&", "&&", "*", "∧" Or: "|", "||", "+", "∨", "#" XOr: "^", "⊻" Not: "!", "~", "¬"
As usual AND precedes OR and XOr.
Multiple expressions can be separated by "," or ";". If you want to name the expressions you can use the let-command: "let U=A+B, let V=A*B"

The first line has to contain the names of inputs and outputs. The following lines contain the expected values. A 'X' represents a don't care, and a 'Z' represents a high Z value. If a 'C' is used, at first all other values are set, after that a clock cycle is performed and than the values are compared. So it's easier to test sequential logic. A line which starts with a number sign ('#') is a comment.
So a test for a 2-bit counter could look like this:
C Q1 Q0 0 0 0 C 0 1 C 1 0 C 1 1 C 0 0
The tests are executed by Run->Run Tests.
